rdf:Description.vra:description: "In 25 'chapters', Carrión described all manner of human relationships simply by using names, which he arranged in ever-varying typographical relationships. The names approach one another, sometimes blend together and then separate again. Arguments is a sublime interpretation of the statement that he published that same year: "All existing things are structures. Everything that happens is a metaphor. Every metaphor is a meeting point of two structures."--Metropolis M. magazine, 2010, number 5.;Artist's book.

rdf:Description.vra:description: Title from box.;Artist's book.;"Blessing Bowl is a book of blessings offered and received as part of daily life. Inspired by Buddhist monks (bhikkhus) who live their lives dependent on the alms or blessings placed in the bowl. Though most of these blessings are not grandiose they fill my beggar's bowl with all that is needed."--Colophon.;"A flag book structure with a circular format wraps around and comes together in the shape of a bowl. The blessings flow towards the center. Text is set in 12 pt Gills Sans and printed on a Vandercook letterpress from photopolymer plates. The bowl and blessing are Strathmore and Neenah over paper. The box is covered in Thai Unryu"--Colophon.

rdf:Description.vra:description: Title and publishers from colophon; date from signatures.;Edition of six signed and numbered copies.;"A collaborative project initiated by Drew Matott and Drew Cameron of the People's Republic of Paper along with members of Iraq Veterans Against the War. Utilizing uniforms that they wore in combat, the veterans cut, cooked and beat their uniforms into pulp and used a spray-pulp printing technique to render images and text onto the sheets. This series was made from the uniforms of Chanan Suarez-Diaz, Jon Michael Turner, Adrienne Kinne, Drew Cameron, Cloy Richards, Matt Howard, Eli Wright, Nate Lewis, Mike Blake, Phil Aliff"--Colophon.;Issued unbound in envelope of handmade paper with ribbon and button closure. The image printed on the envelope is different for each copy in the edition.;Six of the sheets contain a series of images of a man removing/tearing away his military uniform; the two remaining sheets contain a poem and colophon.;The photographs were taken by Hannah Carpenter Pitkin, cf. OCLC 183890991.

rdf:Description.vra:description: Title from spine.;Artist's book consisting of 3 sets of prints housed in a linen-covered clamshell box divided into three compartments. The forty-two print elements can be pieced together to form fourteen prints, which measure 10" x 14" each. Printed on the verso of each print are excerpts "from a manuscript that the artist discovered while in residency at the American Antiquarian Society in the fall of 2000. The handwritten pages, which numbered over three hundred in length, comprised the transcript for a series of congressional hearings held in 1871. The purpose of the hearings was to gain information about the activities of the group known at that time as the Ku Klux, a widespread organization that was responsible for a virtual reign of terror throughout the south in the decades following the civil war. The transcripts bear witness not only to the horrific acts of the KK, but also to the way in which they divided a community along racial lines by targeting anyone who resisted their vision of racial separation and white supremacy"--Colophon.;"To produce the printed pieces, multiple layers of text and imagery were hand silkscreened onto sheets of Arches Cover, then hand-colored. The images used for the prints are period photographs and engravings collected by the artist"--Colophon.;Limited edition of 40 copies.

rdf:Description.vra:description: "This book is printed in a limited edition of one hundred copies with ten artist's proofs. Each book is numbered and signed by C. David Thomas and Charles Fenn. All pages are printed on Vietnamese Do (mulberry) paper handmade in Dong O Village in northern Vietnam. The images are printed from a Hewlett-Packard Deskjet 970Cse. The text is printed letterpress in Monotype Bembo by Wolfe Editions in Portland, Maine. Each book is presented in a lacquer box handmade by craftsmen in Thanh Tri Village near Hanoi ... The lacquer box is contained in a handmade silk slipcover, also made in Vietnam. The silk was handwoven in Van Phuc Village near Hanoi"--Colophon.;"Incorporates passages from a fictional "diary" [of H̀ô Chí Minh] ... based on historical documents ... Also included are passages from Prison diary, a collection of poems written by H̀ô Chí Minh while he was in prison"--page 13.

rdf:Description.vra:description: Flag book structure with accordion structure binding. "The illustrations are hand carved linoleum blocks ... the binding was constructed by hand as well ... The project was funded in part by the California Arts Council ... Produced in a class taught by California Arts Council artist-in-residence, Bonnie Thompson Norman, at the Women's Building"--Colophon.;Letterpress printed collaborative artists' book produced as a class project in a course taught by California Arts Council artist-in-residence, Bonnie Thompson Norman. Students included are Kimmer Enoedy, Julia Akiko Seko, Dan Strehl, Bella Mokover and Martina Wilson. Illustrations are linocuts. The binding is a concertina with paper covered boards based on a concept by Hedi Kyle and commonly called her flag book.

rdf:Description.vra:description: Collective cover title. Each volume has "Martyr, Mercury, & Rooster" printed on pages 1 of cover, with the title of the respective book printed in light gray and the others printed blind. Each volume also has individual title-page.;A collaborative project between Caren Heft and Jeffrey Morin. Various colored and textured Root Mill cotton, Larroque and Hahnemuhle papers. Ornamentation includes onlays of metal, string, tape, plastic, pins, mica, beads and paper. All books printed in 14 point Cochin Light. Pale blue-green textured cloth dropback box with small mica square inlaid on front.;Sibongile and the murderous rooster is illustrated with multi-color linocuts.;Edition of 50.

rdf:Description.vra:description: Artist's book.;"Designed, printed, and bound by Maria Veronica San Martin. Images are etchings, dry points, aquatint, woodcuts, and screenprints printed on Rives BFK heavyweight cream paper. Typeface is Courier and Elemental Sans."--Colophon.;"'Memory and Landscape: Unveiling the Historic Truths of Chile' is a book of resistance that carries forward the protest and history of the disappearance of people in Chile during the dictatorship of Augusto Pinochet."--[Preface];Text includes a timeline of events 1973-1990, biographies of the disappeared and executed in Chile, and a list of disappeared detainees and executed in Chile. Images are accordion-folded with portraits of the disappeared and executed on one side, and depictions of historic events during the military dictatorship on the other.
